fields.message: Congratulations on your pregnancy! Have you gone to the clinic? You should be checked at least 4 times at a health centre to ensure a healthy pregnancy/baby.
fields.name: 01-1-ANC

fields.message: Have you told someone you trust about your pregnancy? Tell your partner, a friend or family member early on so that they can support you.
fields.name: 01-3-ANC

fields.message: Do you know your HIV status? Mothers can prevent their babies from being infected with HIV by taking action. Visit a health centre with your partner for testing
fields.name: 01-5-PMTCT

fields.message: Do you sleep under a mosquito net at night to stop malaria? Malaria harms a mothers and babies. It causes babies to be born small or born dead. Get a net!
fields.name: 02-1-Malaria

fields.message: Stay healthy! Drink a lot of boiled water, juice and milk. Eat healthy four times a day: fruit, vegetables, beans or g-nuts. Eggs, meat or fish two times a week
fields.name: 02-3-Nutrition

fields.message: Have you gone for your first health visit? Every pregnant woman should go to the health centre for at least 4 visits. Go as soon as you know you are pregnant.
fields.name: 02-5-ANC

fields.message: Do you know where you will have your baby? What will you do if there is a problem during pregnancy? Speak with your family or health worker now, to make a plan.
fields.name: 03-1-Birth Planning

fields.message: Go to a health centre NOW if you have vaginal bleeding, fever, bad headache or blurred vision, swelling of face or body, convulsions or bad pain in lower  belly
fields.name: 03-4-Danger Signs

fields.message: Do you know that the move of HIV from mother to child can be stopped? If you have HIV remember to take your medicine to prevent your baby from getting infected.
fields.name: 04-1-PMTCT

fields.message: You can prevent malaria by closing your windows and doors before dark and sleeping under a net every night. Visit a health worker if you need a mosquito net!
fields.name: 04-3-Malaria

fields.message: Make a pregnancy plan: Where to go for treatment? How to get there? Is there money set aside? Who will help at home if you are away? Talk to family and friends.
fields.name: 04-5-Birth Planning

fields.message: Know danger signs like vaginal bleeding, severe belly pain, fever, headache, blurred vision or swelling. Go to the health centre NOW if you have these problems.
fields.name: 05-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: Women should give birth in a health clinic with a doctor, nurse or midwife. Where will you give birth? Talk to a health worker, family or friends. Make a plan
fields.name: 05-3-Birth Planning

fields.message: Have you and your partner been tested? Go to a health centre for HIV testing and talk to a health worker about preventing infection of your baby.
fields.name: 06-1-PMTCT

fields.message: Have you visited a clinic? Visit the health centre to check for anaemia, sphyilis, HIV and TB, and to get medicine to build your blood, for malaria and tetanus.
fields.name: 06-3-ANC

fields.message: Stay healthy! Preganant women should not use alcohol, drugs, tobacco or herbal medicines because these can harm your baby.
fields.name: 06-5-Nutrition

fields.message: Keep your body clean by bathing regularly. Brush your teeth every day.  Always wash your hands after using the latrine, before eating and before preparing food.
fields.name: 07-1-Hygiene

fields.message: How will you get to a health clinic when you go into labour? Is there enough money to go there? Make a plan and discuss with your partner, friends and family.
fields.name: 07-3-Birth Planning

fields.message: You should always use a condom during sex. If you don't have HIV, condoms can protect you and your baby. Talk about it with your health worker and your partner.
fields.name: 07-5-PMTCT

fields.message: Do you know your HIV status? An infected woman can protect her baby by taking action. Visit a clinic with your partner for tests and help keep your baby safe!
fields.name: 08-1-PMTCT

fields.message: If you have fever, headache, joint paints, poor appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, chest pain or look pale, go to a health centre now for help with malaria.
fields.name: 08-4-Malaria

fields.message: Drink safe and boiled water! Do not drink water directly from lakes, ponds and rivers. Do not eat soil or clay. This can make you and your baby sick.
fields.name: 09-1-Nutrition

fields.message: Pregnancy is a wonderful time but you may also have worries.Talk about your pregnancy with your partner, friends and family members so they can support you.
fields.name: 09-3-Birth Planning

fields.message: If you have vaginal discharge, sores on your private parts, or pain in lower belly go to a health clinic NOW to get help for the health of you and your baby!
fields.name: 10-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: At the health clinic a health worker will check your blood pressure and feel your belly. They will tell you around what date your baby should be born.
fields.name: 10-3-ANC

fields.message: Eat 4 meals a day and bites between meals. Eat a variety of foods like bread, rice, fruit, vegetables, meat. Do not get thirsty, drink boiled water and juice.
fields.name: 11-1-Nutrition

fields.message: Who will go with you to the clinic when you go into labour? Choose someone you trust and who can make decisions for you if needed. Make a plan with this person.
fields.name: 11-4-Birth Planning

fields.message: Are you taking iron and folate tablets? They are important for a healthy baby and to maintain a mother's blood level.  Make sure you take them every day!
fields.name: 12-1-Nutrition

fields.message: What date is your baby due? Start planning with your partner, family and health worker so that you are prepared when the time comes.
fields.name: 12-4-Birth Planning

fields.message: Congratulations on your pregnancy! Have you gone for your first health visit? Go for your first visit as soon as possible for the health of you and your baby!
fields.name: 13-1-ANC

fields.message: Do you know your HIV status? Mothers can prevent their babies from being infected with HIV by taking action. Visit a health centre with your partner for testing
fields.name: 13-3-PMTCT

fields.message: Eat 4 meals a day and bites between meals. Eat a variety of foods like bread, rice, fruit, vegetables, meat. Do not get thirsty, drink boiled water and juice.
fields.name: 13-6-Nutrition

fields.message: Pregnant women are more likely to get malaria. At your 2nd and 3rd health visit you will get medicine SP or Fansidar to prevent malaria. It's safe for your baby
fields.name: 14-1-Malaria

fields.message: What date is your baby due? Start planning with your partner, family and health worker now, so that you are prepared when the time comes.
fields.name: 14-3-Birth Planning

fields.message: Go to a health centre NOW if you have vaginal bleeding, fever, bad headache or blurred vision, swelling of face or body, convulsions or bad pain in lower  belly
fields.name: 14-5-Danger Signs

fields.message: Have you gone for your first health visit? Every pregnant woman should go to the health centre for at least 4 visits. Go as soon as you know you are pregnant.
fields.name: 15-1-ANC

fields.message: Women should give birth in a health clinic with a doctor, nurse or midwife. Where will you give birth? Talk to a health worker, family or friends. Make a plan
fields.name: 15-4-Birth Planning

fields.message: If you are HIV positive, talk with your health worker and make a plan for breastfeeding. Your baby will be well nourished and safe!
fields.name: 16-1-PMTCT

fields.message: Do you sleep under a mosquito net at night to stop malaria? Malaria harms a mothers and babies. It causes babies to be born small or born dead. Get a net!
fields.name: 16-3-Malaria

fields.message: Are you taking iron and folate tablets? They are important for a healthy baby and to maintain a mother's blood level.  Make sure you take them every day!
fields.name: 16-6-Nutrition

fields.message: Go to the clinic to check for diseases that harm you or your baby. A health worker will check your blood pressure and your belly to see how the baby is growing.
fields.name: 17-1-ANC

fields.message: Keep your body clean by bathing regularly. Brush your teeth every day.  Always wash your hands after using the latrine, before eating and before preparing food.
fields.name: 17-4-Hygiene

fields.message: How will you get to a health clinic when you go into labour? Is there enough money to go there? Make a plan and discuss with your partner, friends and family.
fields.name: 18-1-Birth Planning

fields.message: If you have vaginal discharge, sores on your private parts, or pain in lower belly go to a health clinic NOW to get help for the health of you and your baby!
fields.name: 18-3-Danger Signs

fields.message: Do you know that the move of HIV from mother to child can be stopped? If you have HIV remember to take your medicine to prevent your baby from getting infected.
fields.name: 18-6-PMTCT

fields.message: At the clinic you will be asked questions: How are you feeling? Do you eat well? Do you sleep under a net? Are you taking tablets? Tell them about any problems.
fields.name: 19-1-ANC

fields.message: Do you use a mosquito net at night? Prevent malaria by closing windows and doors before dark and sleeping under a net. Talk to a health worker about a net.
fields.name: 19-4-Malaria

fields.message: You should always use a condom during sex. If you don't have HIV, condoms can protect you and your baby. Talk about it with your health worker and your partner.
fields.name: 20-1-PMTCT

fields.message: Take your iron and folate tablets every evening after a meal. Iron may make your poo black but don't worry! Tell your health worker if you have any problems.
fields.name: 20-3-Nutrition

fields.message: Who will go with you to the clinic when you go into labour? Choose someone you trust and who can make decisions for you if needed. Make a plan with this person.
fields.name: 20-5-Birth Planning

fields.message: If you think that your baby has stopped moving or if you feel contractions before your due date, go to the health clinic NOW for a check.
fields.name: 21-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: At the clinic you should get medicine to build your blood, prevent malaria, treat for worms and protect against tetanus. These are safe for you and your baby.
fields.name: 21-3-ANC

fields.message: If you have fever, headache, joint paints, poor appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, chest pain or look pale, go to a health centre now for help with malaria.
fields.name: 21-5-Malaria

fields.message: Plan for any problems: Where to go for treatment? How to get there? Is there money set aside? Who will help at home if you are away? Talk to family and friends.
fields.name: 22-1-Birth Planning

fields.message: Have you and your partner been tested? Go to a health centre for HIV testing and talk to a health worker about preventing infection of your baby.
fields.name: 22-3-PMTCT

fields.message: If you have any problems with your pregnancy you may need to have more than four health visits. Follow the advice that your health worker gives you.
fields.name: 22-6-ANC

fields.message: Have you felt the baby move? At the clinic a health worker will feel your belly to check the baby. Usually the top of the womb can be felt at 20 weeks pregnancy
fields.name: 23-1-ANC

fields.message: Stay healthy! Pregnant women should get plenty of rest. They should not take alcohol, drugs, tobacco or herbal medicines because these can harm your baby.
fields.name: 23-3-Nutrition

fields.message: Pregnant women can have malaria without knowing it. It is important to take two doses of SP (Fansidar) to prevent malaria. Have you had your first dose of SP?
fields.name: 23-6-Malaria

fields.message: Know danger signs like vaginal bleeding, severe belly pain, fever, headache, blurred vision or swelling. Go to the health centre NOW if you have these problems.
fields.name: 24-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: Pregnant women should go for at least four health visits. Did you go for a second visit? A health worker will listen to the baby's heart and check its growth.
fields.name: 24-3-ANC

fields.message: If you have HIV you need to take medicine to protect your baby. Tell your health care worker if you know you are infected. Get tested if you don't know!
fields.name: 24-5-PMTCT

fields.message: Every pregnant woman should go for at least 4 health visits. How many times have you gone? If you've not had 3 visits go to the clinic now, it is not too late!
fields.name: 25-1-ANC

fields.message: Do you sleep under a mosquito net at night to stop malaria? Malaria harms a mothers and babies. It causes babies to be born small or born dead. Get a net!
fields.name: 25-4-Malaria

fields.message: Know danger signs like vaginal bleeding, severe belly pain, fever, headache, blurred vision or swelling. Go to the health centre NOW if you have these problems.
fields.name: 26-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: When is your baby due? How will you get to a health clinic when you go into labour? Is there enough money to go there? Plan together with friends and family.
fields.name: 26-3-Birth Planning

fields.message: You should always use a condom during sex. If you don't have HIV, condoms can protect you and your baby. Talk about it with your health worker and your partner.
fields.name: 26-5-PMTCT

fields.message: Pregnancy is a wonderful time but you may also have worries.Talk about your pregnancy with your partner, friends and family members so they can support you.
fields.name: 27-1-ANC

fields.message: Eat 4 meals a day and bites between meals. Eat a variety of foods like bread, rice, fruit, vegetables, meat. Do not get thirsty, drink boiled water and juice.
fields.name: 27-4-Nutrition

fields.message: It is imprtant to give birth in a health clinic with a nurse, midwife or doctor.  Make a plan with your health worker, partner, friends and family.
fields.name: 28-1-Birth Planning

fields.message: Go to a health centre NOW if you have vaginal bleeding, fever, bad headache or blurred vision, swelling of face or body, convulsions or bad pain in lower  belly
fields.name: 28-3-Danger Signs

fields.message: Do you know your HIV status? Mothers can prevent their babies from being infected with HIV by taking action. Visit a health centre with your partner for testing
fields.name: 28-5-PMTCT

fields.message: Every pregnant woman should go for at least 4 health centre visits. Have you gone for your fourth visit yet?
fields.name: 29-1-ANC

fields.message: You can prevent malaria by closing your windows and doors before dark and sleeping under a net every night. Visit a health worker if you need a mosquito net!
fields.name: 29-3-Malaria

fields.message: Keep your body clean by bathing regularly. Brush your teeth every day.  Always wash your hands after using the latrine, before eating and before preparing food.
fields.name: 29-5-Hygiene

fields.message: Who will go with you to the health clinic when you are in labour? Choose someone you trust who can make decisions for you in case you can't. Plan together.
fields.name: 30-1-Birth Planning

fields.message: Do you know that the move of HIV from mother to child can be stopped? If you have HIV remember to take your medicine to prevent your baby from getting infected.
fields.name: 30-3-PMTCT

fields.message: Are you taking iron and folate tablets? They are important for a healthy baby and to maintain a mother's blood level.  Make sure you take them every day!
fields.name: 30-5-Nutrition

fields.message: Malaria can cause problems for the baby and mother: low birth weight, stillbirth and even death. Did you get a ITN voucher from the clinic to prevent malaria?
fields.name: 31-1-Malaria

fields.message: If you have vaginal discharge, sores on your private parts, or pain in lower belly go to a health clinic NOW to get help for the health of you and your baby!
fields.name: 31-4-Danger Signs

fields.message: Plan for any problems: Where to go for treatment? How to get there? Is there money set aside? Who will help at home if you are away? Talk to family and friends.
fields.name: 32-1-Birth Planning

fields.message: Stay healthy! Pregnant women should get plenty of rest. They should not take alcohol, drugs, tobacco or herbal medicines because these can harm your baby.
fields.name: 32-3-Nutrition

fields.message: If you are HIV positive, talk with your health worker and make a plan for breastfeeding. Your baby will be well nourished and safe!
fields.name: 32-5-PMTCT

fields.message: If you have any problems with your pregnancy you may need to have more than four health visits. Follow the advice that your health worker gives you.
fields.name: 33-1-ANC

fields.message: Pregnant women should take SP even when they are not sick because they are more likely to get malaria or they don't know they are sick. It is safe for the baby.
fields.name: 33-4-Malaria

fields.message: If you are HIV positive make sure to give birth at a clinic and tell the health worker about your status. You can get medicine to protect your baby from HIV.
fields.name: 34-1-PMTCT

fields.message: Know signs of labour: If you have strong pains in the lower belly and back, bloody mucous or water leaking from the vagina go to the health clinic right away!
fields.name: 34-4-Birth Planning

fields.message: At the clinic a health worker will feel your belly to check baby's growth,  position and heart. They will also check your blood level, blood pressure and urine.
fields.name: 35-1-ANC

fields.message: It is very important for pregnant women to receive a second dose of SP (Fansidar) to prevent malaria during pregnancy. Have you had your second dose of SP?
fields.name: 35-3-Malaria

fields.message: Have you the things you need for a clean birth and to keep you and baby warm? Make sure you have clean khangas orkitenges to go with you to clinic for birth.
fields.name: 35-5-Birth Planning

fields.message: After your baby is born, make sure that you both sleep under a mosquito net to prevent malaria. Talk with your health worker if you do not have a mosquito net.
fields.name: 36-1-Malaria

fields.message: If you have gone past your due date go to a clinic to check the baby. They may give you medicine to make you go into labour or plan for caesarean section.
fields.name: 36-4-Birth Planning

fields.message: If you have fever, headache, joint paints, poor appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, chest pain or look pale, go to a health centre now for help with malaria.
fields.name: 37-1-Malaria

fields.message: You are almost there, hold on! Have you made all the needed plans for giving birth? Do you have money you need to get to the health centre?
fields.name: 37-3-Birth Planning

fields.message: Congratulations it is almost time! You should be visited by a health worker 3 times and go with baby to the clinic during the first week after the baby is born.
fields.name: 37-5-ANC

fields.message: At the clinic a health worker will talk to you about labour: regular pains in the belly and back that get stronger, bloody mucous and water leaking from vagina.
fields.name: 38-1-ANC

fields.message: If you think that your baby has stopped moving or if you feel contractions before your due date, go to the health clinic NOW for a check.
fields.name: 38-4-Danger Signs

fields.message: Every woman and her baby should be seen by a health worker at a health clinic in the first week after delivery. Have you gone to the clinic after giving birth?
fields.name: 39-1-PNC

fields.message: You know that the move of HIV from mother to child can be stopped? If you have HIV you and baby must take medicine to protect the baby.Go to clinic for medicine
fields.name: 39-4-PMTCT

fields.message: Breastmilk is the only food your baby needs for the first 6 months of life! Ask your health worker for help if you are having any problems with breastfeeding.
fields.name: 39-5-Nutrition

fields.message: Breastmilk is the only food your baby needs for the first 6 months of life! Give your baby only breastmilk and nothing else to eat or drink until 6 months.
fields.name: 40-1-Nutrition

fields.message: Did you know that you can get pregnant again soon after delivery? Talk to your partner and health worker about using condoms and preventing unplanned pregnancy.
fields.name: 40-3-Birth Spacing

fields.message: Go to clinic NOW if you have: bleeding or bad smelling fluid from vagina, pain in  belly, fever,headache, blurred vision, or problems breathing or breastfeeding
fields.name: 40-5-Danger Signs

fields.message: At your first visit after birth a health worker will check your baby's health and give medicines. Have your baby checked during the first week after delivery.
fields.name: 41-1-PNC

fields.message: Do you know your HIV status? Mothers can prevent their babies from being infected with HIV by taking action. Visit a health centre with your partner for testing
fields.name: 41-3-PMTCT

fields.message: Prevent malaria by sleeping with your baby under a mosquito net every night.  Talk with your health worker if you do not have a mosquito net.
fields.name: 41-5-Malaria

fields.message: Go to the health clinic NOW if your baby has fever, problems breathing, cries all the time, is unable to suck, moves less than normal or has bad shaking.
fields.name: 42-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: Go to the clinic for a check during the first week after giving birth. A health worker will check to see you are well. Tell them if you are having any problems.
fields.name: 42-3-PNC

fields.message: Remember to keep your baby warm and dry after birth and put them on the breast within the first hour of life.
fields.name: 42-5-PNC

fields.message: Keep umbilical cord clean and dry and do not apply anything. It will fall off after 10 to 21 days. If cord looks red, hot or swollen go to health centre.
fields.name: 43-1-PNC

fields.message: Go to the health clinic NOW if your baby has bleeding, fever, shaking, cries all the time, can't feed well or is not moving much.
fields.name: 43-3-PNC

fields.message: Go to the health clinic for a check 6 weeks after the baby is born. A health worker will check your health and baby's growth, test for HIV and give medicines.
fields.name: 44-1-PNC

fields.message: Did you know that you can get pregnant again soon after delivery? Talk to your partner and health worker about using condoms and preventing unplanned pregnancy.
fields.name: 44-3-Birth Spacing

fields.message: If you are HIV positive, your baby can be tested for HIV when 6 weeks old. Take your baby to the clinic for a check and HIV testing at 6 weeks after birth.
fields.name: 44-6-PMTCT

fields.message: Breast milk is the only food your baby needs for the first 6 months of life!  Give your baby only breastmilk and nothing else until they are 6 months old.
fields.name: 45-1-Nutrition

fields.message: Malaria is very dangerous to babies! Prevent malaria by sleeping with your baby under a mosquito net. Talk to a health worker if you do not have a net.
fields.name: 45-3-Malaria

fields.message: Go to clinic NOW if you have: bleeding or bad smelling fluid from vagina, pain in  belly, fever,headache, blurred vision, or problems breathing or breastfeeding
fields.name: 45-5-Danger Signs

fields.message: Take your baby to a health clinic at 6 weeks old. A health worker will check the baby's weight, give medicines and will test baby for HIV if you are positive.
fields.name: 46-1-PNC

fields.message: Breast milk is the only food your baby needs for the first 6 months of life! Ask your health worker for help if you have any trouble with breastfeeding.
fields.name: 46-3-Nutrition

fields.message: Go to the health clinic NOW if your baby has fever, problems breathing, cries all the time, is unable to suck, moves less than normal or has bad shaking.
fields.name: 46-5-Danger Signs

fields.message: Malaria is very dangerous to babies! Prevent malaria by closing windows and doors before dark and sleeping with baby under a net. No Net? Talk to health worker.
fields.name: 47-1-Malaria

fields.message: Be sure to take your baby to the health clinic for medicines and a check-up at 6 weeks. See a health worker NOW if your baby has any problems.
fields.name: 47-3-PNC

fields.message: If you have HIV it is important that you and your baby take medicine to protect the baby from HIV. Go to a health clinic for medicine if you don't have any.
fields.name: 47-5-PMTCT

fields.message: When you are breastfeeding eat 3 or 4 meals with a variety of fruit,vegetables,meat,rice and bread every day. Drink lots of boiled water and fresh fruit juice.
fields.name: 48-1-Nutrition

fields.message: If you have fever, headache, joint paints, poor appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, chest pain or look pale, go to a health centre now for help with malaria.
fields.name: 48-3-Malaria

fields.message: Stay healthy while you are breastfeeding! Get plenty of rest.  Avoid alcohol, drugs, tobacco and herbal medicines, as these can harm your baby.
fields.name: 48-6-Nutrition

fields.message: Have you taken your baby to the health clinic for medicines and testing?  Take your baby for a check-up and be sure that the birth has been registered.
fields.name: 49-1-PNC

fields.message: If you are HIV positive, your baby can be tested for HIV at 6 weeks old. Take your baby to the health clinic for testing now if you don't know their status.
fields.name: 49-4-PMTCT

fields.message: Breast milk is the only food your baby needs for the first 6 months of life!  Give your baby only breastmilk and nothing else until they are 6 months old.
fields.name: 50-1-Nutrition

fields.message: Malaria is very dangerous to babies! Prevent malaria by closing windows and doors before dark and sleeping with baby under a net. No Net? Talk to health worker.
fields.name: 50-3-Malaria

fields.message: Taking tea leaves, herbs or bathing after sex will NOT prevent pregnancy. Talk with your health worker about ways to prevent unplanned pregnancy.
fields.name: 50-5-Birth Spacing

fields.message: Go to clinic NOW if you have: bleeding or bad smelling fluid from vagina, pain in  belly, fever,headache, blurred vision, or problems breathing or breastfeeding
fields.name: 51-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: If you have HIV or if your baby was early or had low birth weight you should go to the health clinic at least 6 times during first 6 months after birth.
fields.name: 51-4-PNC

fields.message: Do you know your baby's HIV status? Go to a health clinic if you are HIV positive and your baby has not been tested yet.
fields.name: 52-1-PMTCT

fields.message: Breast milk is the only food your baby needs for the first 6 months of life! Ask your health worker for help if you have any trouble with breastfeeding.
fields.name: 52-3-Nutrition

fields.message: If you have fever, headache, joint paints, poor appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, chest pain or look pale, go to a health centre now for help with malaria.
fields.name: 52-5-Malaria

fields.message: Did you know that you can get pregnant again soon after delivery? Talk to your partner and health worker about using condoms and preventing unplanned pregnancy.
fields.name: 53-1-Birth Spacing

fields.message: Have you and baby been to the health centre lately? It is important that you are seen by a health worker at 6 weeks and at 6 months after the baby is born.
fields.name: 53-4-PNC

fields.message: If you are HIV positive, do not forget to give your baby medicine to prevent HIV.  Be sure to store HIV drugs away from sunlight so that they stay fresh.
fields.name: 54-1-PMTCT

fields.message: When you are breastfeeding eat 3 or 4 meals with a variety of fruit,vegetables,meat,rice and bread every day. Drink lots of boiled water and fresh fruit juice.
fields.name: 54-3-Nutrition

fields.message: Getting pregnant soon after your delivery can be unhealthy. Have you considered birth spacing? Speak to your partner and to a health worker.
fields.name: 54-6-Birth Spacing

fields.message: If your baby is not feeding well this could be a sign that they are very sick. Take your baby to a health clinic NOW if they are not feeding well.
fields.name: 55-1-Danger Signs

fields.message: At a 6 month visit, a health worker will check baby weight/height, give medicine and talk about what foods they can eat. Don't forget a 6 month visit to clinic!
fields.name: 55-3-PNC

fields.message: Breastmilk is the healthiest food for your baby. HIV positive moms and their babies must take medicine for all the time they breastfeed.Talk to a health worker!
fields.name: 55-5-PMTCT

fields.message: Using family planning will not make you infertile. Planning is safe, reversible and you can choose time for next baby. Talk to your partner and a health worker!
fields.name: 56-1-Birth Spacing

fields.message: Go to the health clinic NOW if your baby has fever, problems breathing, cries all the time, is unable to suck, moves less than normal or has bad shaking.
fields.name: 56-4-Danger Signs

fields.message: At a health visit 6 months after birth a health worker will examine and talk to you about staying healthy. Ask them about how to prevent unplanned pregnancy!
fields.name: 57-1-PNC

fields.message: If you are HIV positive, remember that you and your baby both need to take medicine to prevent your baby from catching HIV.
fields.name: 57-3-PMTCT

fields.message: How is the baby growing? Breast milk is the only food your baby needs during the first 6 months. Talk to a health worker about what to feed baby after 6 months.
fields.name: 57-5-Nutrition

fields.message: Malaria is very dangerous to babies! Prevent malaria by sleeping with your baby under a mosquito net. Talk to a health worker if you do not have a net.
fields.name: 58-1-Malaria

fields.message: Take your baby to the health clinic for HIV testing when they are 6 weeks old and again when they stop breastfeeding. Go get the help and medicine you need.
fields.name: 58-4-PMTCT

fields.message: Did you know that HIV positive women still need to take medicine after they stop breastfeeding? Stay healthy for yourself and your baby. See your health worker.
fields.name: 59-1-PMTCT

fields.message: Stay healthy while you are breastfeeding! Get plenty of rest.  Avoid alcohol, drugs, tobacco and herbal medicines, as these can harm your baby.
fields.name: 59-4-Nutrition
